item.title: Now is now. Next time is next time.
item.description:
A film that’s stuck with me since I watched it is Wim Wender’s Perfect Days. Perfect Days follows Hirayama, a janitor in Tokyo, through his monotonous, unchanging daily routine. Despite this seemingly simplistic lifestyle, Hirayama appears (on the surface at least) deeply contented.

The film serves as a meditation on the importance of being present. Hirayama is present for every small moment of his day; he takes pleasure in watching the sunlight filter through the trees, in the books he reads, and in caring for his Bonsai trees.

item.title: A Total Ordering on Films
item.description: The train of thought that culminated in this project set off when my good friend (Rish) sent me a list compiled by the New York Times of the “100 Best Movies of the 21st Century”. Scrolling through the list idle mindedly, I picked out the films which I’d seen, silently agreeing with the list for including them. However, when given more thought, I started to wonder the methodology behind this ranking.

item.title: Tales from the Golden Peninsula
item.description:
It’s 23:30 on a Saturday as I write this. Really I should be working towards an upcoming paper deadline. However, having just watched The Motorcycle Diaries, I feel suddenly enthused to write this instead.

Though my time spent travelling South East Asia was incomparably less impactful than Ernesto’s time on the roads of South America, I look back on my time travelling fondly. I spent the last half an hour recounting the tales in my head, recalling the faces I saw and the stories I exchanged with them.
